abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Padma Multipurpose
            Bridge Project for Bangladesh were as follows: outcomes were
            not applicable, risk to development outcome was not
            applicable, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory. The project was designed to
            connect the isolated southwestern region with the rest of
            the country, as well as reduce travel times countrywide and
            connect the country's two seaports. The Bank
            investigated allegations of corruption and provided evidence
            to the Government of Bangladesh (GoB), which referred these
            to the Anti-Corruption Commission of Bangladesh (ACC). The
            Bank reached an agreement with the GoB on the appointment by
            the Bank of an external expert panel to assess the adequacy
            of the Government's investigation of the allegations.
            Following completion of the Panel's report, the GoB
            informed the Bank on January 31, 2013 that it was
            withdrawing its request for World Bank financing for the
            Padma bridge project.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Executive Directors approved the
            Credit for the Padma Multipurpose Bridge Project for the
            Peoples' Republic of Bangladesh in the amount of
            SDR779.3 million (US$1.2 billion equivalent) on the terms
            and conditions set out in the President's Memorandum.
            Executive Directors expressed strong support for this
            transformative investment which will connect the isolated
            southwest region, the home of about 30 million people, to
            the rest of the country. Directors endorsed the World
            Bank's role as the coordinating financier and took note
            of the strong Governance and Accountability Action Plan
            (GAAP), the envisaged robust social and environmental
            safeguard measures, and the implementation arrangements.
            They underscored the need for careful monitoring of the
            governance, fiduciary, as well the social and environmental
            aspects of this technically challenging operation, and the
            proper coordination among the co-financiers.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Padma Multipurpose
            Bridge Project for Bangladesh is to connect the south-
            western region to the rest of the country in order to
            stimulate economic growth by facilitating inter-regional,
            cross-river transport of passengers and freight, and
            transmission of natural gas, telecommunication and
            electricity in a cost effective manner. There are five
            components to the project, the first component being main
            bridge and approach roads. This component will include
            construction of foundation, substructure and superstructure
            of the main bridge and services on the bridge, road
            viaducts, approach roads, toll plazas and bridge end
            facilities. This would be a 'rail ready' road
            bridge. The second component is the river training works.
            The third component is the implementation of social action
            and environmental management plans. This component will
            support implementation of the social action plan including
            the Resettlement Action Plans (RAP), public health action,
            gender action, charland monitoring and public consultation
            plans. The fourth component is the construction supervision,
            monitoring and evaluation of the project impact and social
            and environmental management plans. This component will
            cover the cost of consulting and other services for project
            implementation, including construction supervision and
            project management support. Finally, the fifth component is
            the project management support, capacity building of
            Bangladesh Bridge Authority (BBA), technical assistance and training.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Padma Multipurpose Bridge
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The main development objective of the
            Padma Multipurpose Bridge Project for Bangladesh is to
            establish a permanent road crossing, including a provision
            for a future railway crossing over the Padma River,
            replacing the existing unreliable and unsafe ferries.
            Negative impacts include: air quality, noise pollution,
            surface water quality, traffic, groundwater quality,
            riverbed sediment quality, and stockpiling of dredged
            material. Mitigation measures include: 1) use piling system
            with lowest sound generation, silent sleepers on bridge; 2)
            consider creation of an artificial char at a location with
            low erosion; 3) clearance from relevant environmental
            authorities; 4) suitable waste disposal and processing
            facilities; 5) restrict movement of vessels, barges,
            dredgers to designated areas; 6) keep night-time activities
            to a minimum; and 7) speed reduction devices on bridge for traffic/train.

Bangladesh - Multipurpose Bridge Project :
            environmental and social impact assessment - executive summary

abstracts.cdata!:
A prefeasibility study for the Padma
            Multipurpose Bridge Project was carried out in 2000. It
            investigated a number of potential alignments for the
            proposed bridge. On the basis of the outcome of that study
            Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), at the
            request of Government of Bangladesh (GOB), carried out a
            feasibility study (FS) in 2002-2004. This study concluded
            that the most feasible bridge site is at Mawa-Janjira point.
            The selection of this site was subsequently approved by GOB.
            The FS included, among others, a preliminary technical
            design, economic and financial evaluation, a framework for
            land acquisition and a Resettlement Action Plan (RAP),
            Initial Environmental Examination (IEE), and an
            Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA). As the FS concluded
            that Padma Bridge is economically viable, GOB moved forward
            for implementation and accordingly BBA conducted a study to
            update the previous EIA and to prepare an Environmental
            Management Plan (EMP), a Land Acquisition Plan (LAP) and a
            Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) in 2006. The Asian
            Development Bank (ADB) also conducted a FS including an EIA
            and resettlement plan in 2007. The studies formed the basis
            for the decision of GOB to proceed with second phase, which
            includes the detailed engineering design and implementation
            of the project funded by an ADB technical assistance (TA)
            loan. In 2009 a safeguard team on environmental and social
            issues, and part of the design consultant's team,
            started the detailed EIA study in accordance with the
            relevant laws and regulations in Bangladesh and EIA
            guidelines of all the co-financiers. The main development
            objective of the project is to establish a permanent road
            crossing, including a provision for a future railway
            crossing over the Padma River, replacing the existing
            unreliable and unsafe ferries.
